[**Definition**]{} The *$\operatorname{sinc}$-* is the function
$\operatorname{sinc}:{\mathbb{R}}\to {\mathbb{R}}$ defined as
$$\begin{aligned}
 \operatorname{sinc}(x) &=& \left\{ \begin {array}{ll} \frac{\sin x}{x} & \mbox{when}\,\, x\neq 0, \\
 1 & \mbox{when}\,\, x= 0.
 \end{array} \right.
 \end{aligned}$$

In some situations, it is more convenient to work with an alternative
“normalized variant,” in which for $x\neq 0$ we redefine the function as
$$\begin{aligned}
\operatorname{sinc}(x)=\frac{\sin(\pi x)}{\pi x}.\end{aligned}$$

The remainder of this entry deals with the initial definition, though
most properties can clearly be suitably modified for the normalized
version.

### Properties {#properties .unnumbered}

-   Using a Taylor expansion of $\sin$, one can show that
    $\operatorname{sinc}$ is infinitely many times differentiable. In
    particular, $\operatorname{sinc}$ is continuous. In this sense, the
    value $1$ for $x=0$ is motivated.

-   Jordan’s inequality implies that $|\operatorname{sinc}(x)|\le 1$ for
    all $x\in {\mathbb{R}}$. More generally, one can also show that all
    derivatives of $\operatorname{sinc}$ are bounded by 1. See .

-   $\operatorname{sinc}$ is an even function.

-   The zeros of $\operatorname{sinc}$ are $x=\pm \pi, \pm 2\pi,\ldots$.

-   $\operatorname{sinc}$ is in $L^2$, but not in $L^1$, and [@gearhart]
    $$\begin{aligned}
    \int_{-\infty}^\infty \operatorname{sinc}(x)\,dx &=& \pi,\\
    \int_{-\infty}^\infty \operatorname{sinc}^2(x)\,dx &=& \pi,\end{aligned}$$
    where the first of these denotes an improper Riemann integral.

-   For all $x\in {\mathbb{R}}$, we have [@gearhart] $$\begin{aligned}
    \operatorname{sinc} (x) &=& \sum_{k=0}^\infty (-1)^k \frac{x^{2k}}{(2k+1)!}, \\
    \operatorname{sinc} (x) &=& \prod_{k=1}^\infty \left(1-\frac{x^2}{(k\pi)^2}\right), \\
    \operatorname{sinc} (x) &=& \prod_{k=1}^\infty \cos \frac{x}{2^k}.\end{aligned}$$

-   The Fourier transform of $\operatorname{sinc}$ is the box function,
    i.e. $$\begin{aligned}
    \operatorname{sinc}(x) = {1\over 2} \int_{-1}^1 e^{ixt} dt.\end{aligned}$$

-   The $\operatorname{sinc}$ function satisfies the differential
    equation $$\begin{aligned}
     x \operatorname{sinc}'' + 2 \operatorname{sinc}' + x \operatorname{sinc} = 0\end{aligned}$$
    This is a consequence of a comment in the sine integral entry.

-   There is no known simple expression for the integral of sinc.
    However, this function is known as the sine integral.

### Synonym and Etymology {#synonym-and-etymology .unnumbered}

The $\operatorname{sinc}$ function is also called or .

### Use {#use .unnumbered}

The sinc function is relevant in several fields. For one, its Fourier
transform is a box, so it is the frequency respose of a perfect on/off
sampling device, and therefore often the correct way to interpolate
between frequencies in a sampled signal. The resulting function is in
fact analytic on the entire complex plane.

College Mathematics Journal, March 1990, Volume 21, Number 2, pp. 90-99.
